options.label: A

title: How do scars form? - Sarthak Sinha

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between healthy skin tissue and scar tissue?

options.label: C
options.text: Scar tissue has a disrupted arrangement of ECM compared to healthy skin tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: Scar tissue has the same composition as healthy skin tissue.

options.text: To produce sweat and control body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: To transport nutrients, facilitate cell-to-cell communication, and promote cell adhesion.

options.label: C
options.text: To inhibit inter-cell processes and reduce durability and elasticity.

options.label: D
options.text: To secrete excessive amounts of collagen.

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of healthy tissue with normal functions.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of scar tissue with reduced function.

options.label: C
options.text: The reduction of ECM in the skin.

options.label: D
options.text: The increase of sweat production in the skin.

multiple-choice.question: What is fibrosis?

options.label: B
options.text: A scarring of the lungs resulting in shortness of breath.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in an organ.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the heart beats faster.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A genetic disorder that causes scarring of the pancreas.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the heart beats slower.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A genetic disorder that causes scarring of the pancreas.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the heart beats faster.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle? - Chad Orzel

multiple-choice.question: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: A fundamental concept in classical physics that states that it is impossible to know the exact position and speed of an object.

options.label: B
options.text: A result of measurement that states that it is impossible to know the exact position and speed of an object.

options.label: C
options.text: A fundamental concept in quantum physics that states that it is impossible to simultaneously know the exact position and speed of an object.

options.label: D
options.text: A mathematical formula that describes the relationship between position and speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: The act of measuring an object's position changes its speed.

options.label: B
options.text: The dual nature of everything in the universe, which behaves like both a particle and a wave at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: The limitations of our ability to measure certain properties.

options.label: D
options.text: The fundamental structure of the universe itself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between an object's wavelength and its momentum?

options.label: A
options.text: An object's wavelength is unrelated to its momentum.

options.label: B
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its mass, but not its velocity.

options.label: C
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its momentum, mass times velocity.

options.label: D
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its velocity, but not its mass.

multiple-choice.question: Who first stated the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?
What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle not just a practical limit on?

options.label: B
options.text: What properties an object can have

options.label: C
options.text: The fundamental structure of the universe itself

options.label: D
options.text: The limitations of our ability to measure certain properties

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the position uncertainty and the momentum uncertainty?

options.label: A
options.text: The position uncertainty is unrelated to the momentum uncertainty.

options.label: B
options.text: The position uncertainty is related to the momentum uncertainty, but only in certain situations.

options.label: C
options.text: The position uncertainty is related to the momentum uncertainty, and the uncertainties are connected.

options.label: D
options.text: The position uncertainty is related to the momentum uncertainty, but only in reverse.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of combining waves with different wavelengths?

options.label: A
options.text: A pure wave with a definite position and momentum.

options.label: B
options.text: A wave packet with a clear wavelength in one small region.

options.label: C
options.text: A wave packet with a good probability of finding it within some range of the center of the wave packet.

options.label: D
options.text: A wave packet with a definite position and momentum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle essential for?

options.label: C
options.text: The study of the fundamental structure of the universe

options.label: D
options.text: The study of the limitations of our ability to measure certain properties

multiple-choice.question: What is the year that the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle was first stated?
Who is the German physicist that first stated the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

title: The chemistry of cold packs - John Pollard

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why cold packs can go from room temperature to near freezing in a short time?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The cold pack is placed in the freezer for several hours before use.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The particles vibrate back and forth.

options.label: C
options.text: The solution remains at room temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Entropy has no role in the cold pack's ability to soothe pain.

options.label: C
options.text: Entropy is responsible for the cold pack's ability to cool the solution.

options.label: D
options.text: Entropy is responsible for the disorder resulting from the dissolution of the solid.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the compound that is usually used in cold packs?

options.label: A
options.text: The particles move rapidly towards each other.

options.label: B
options.text: The particles move slowly away from each other.

options.label: D
options.text: The particles vibrate back and forth.

options.label: C
